The ordered mesoporous Zr-modified MCM-41 materials were synthesized by using four different preparation methods including impregnation method, precipitation method, ultrasound method and trituration method, respectively; active zinc species were immobilized on the modified materials with different methods for introducing zirconia species as effective catalysts for the acetylene hydration. All the synthesized materials were characterized by various techniques including BET, FTIR, XRD, TGA, TEM, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, and solid-stated UV–vis. The correlation between structural properties of zirconia modified support and catalytic performance of the Zn catalysts was evaluated in detailed in the acetylene hydration. It is demonstrate that the Zr-modified materials showed the excellent thermostability, and zirconia species addition could enhance the interactions between active metal and support, as well as control the metal particles size with better dispersion. In addition, the substantial enhancement of acid sites and total acid quantity for the modified materials were contributed to the zirconia species addition. Besides, activity evaluation confirms that the Zn/ZM-P catalyst showed more optimistic catalytic performance above 92% C2H2 conversion and 85% selectivity to acetaldehyde in the acetylene hydration due to the stronger metal-support interactions and more acid sites. The study would provide scientific basis for the design of metal catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Acetylene hydration Zirconia-modified MCM-41 Zn catalyst 1 Introduction As well known, acetylene hydration to acetaldehyde has always been regarded as a highly favored and crucial step to produce acetate and ethanol via anaerobic degradation route of unsaturated hydrocarbons [1–3]. Most importantly, acetylene hydration reaction has been also generally considered as a potential economic process to the chemical industry because the resultant acetaldehyde is of great useful chemical intermediates for many major chemical products, and its worldwide production is over 106 ton/year [4]. In general, the late transition metal ions (especially Zn2+, Cu2+, Ag+, Cd2+, and Hg2+) have been considered as the extensive active ingredients for the acetylene hydration [5–7]. However, the unsatisfactory catalytic properties of the above metal catalysts were obtained in the acetylene hydration, such as the Cd-based catalysts showed the highest activity but with toxic [8], which is gradually obsolete; the Cu-, Ag- and Hg-based catalysts were easily reduced resulted in the deactivation [9]; the Zn-based catalyst showed the high initial activity but of low stability. Recently, to overcome the low stability of Zn catalyst, the introduction of Cu as bimetallic Zn-Cu catalyst produced the high activity with 95% acetylene conversion but with high metal content [10]. In particular, suitable carrier is also a pivotal component for the supported catalysts, in reality, in our previous reports, mesoporous MCM-41 as a feasible carrier has been used in the acetylene hydration [10,11]. In the previous research, zeolites were widespread carriers for the acetylene hydration, while the deactivation for the zeolite catalyst as a result of carbonaceous precipitates. And then, although the zirconia-modified ZSM-5 zeolite supported Zn catalyst displayed above 90% C2H2 conversion, the catalytic stability is unsatisfactory maybe due to the relatively small surface area of the zirconia-modified ZSM-5 zeolite. However, we found that the addition of zirconia provided more weak surface acid sites and enhanced the metal-support interactions [12]. Therefore, we speculate the zirconia modified mesoporous MCM-41 maybe produce a superior active and selective catalyst for the acetylene hydration. Mesoporous MCM-41 as a sort of well-known carrier, there are many praiseworthy advantages, such as a uniform mesoporous channel structure, large internal surface area, accessible pore volume, excellent thermal stabilities and facile surface modification [13–15]. However, the lack of acid sites, lattice imperfection and the almost neutral of surface charge restrict their wide applications in the catalytic system [16,17]. In view of this, many metal ions such as Ti, V, Cr, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, La and Ru have been serviced to dope into MCM-41 silica framework to conquer the above shortcomings, and to make sure the materials as potential catalyst supports [18–20]. In addition, as expected, these modified materials of catalysts have been utilized in catalytic reactions showed the excellent catalytic performance. In generally, the incorporation of metal ions has a significant influence on the metal dispersion, metal-support interaction, acidity and coke formation and others. As well known, zirconia (ZrO2) as a super solid acidic catalyst and phase stabilizer has been given lots of attentions, profiting from its excellent heat-resistance and environment friendly in an atmosphere of oxidation or/and reduction [21,22]. Else, zirconia also is a distinguished and stable promoter to enhance the dispersion and stability for the active metal catalysts due to the strong metal-support interactions [23]. However, the confined of active sites as a result of the low surface area and high crystallinity for the zirconia to limit its home range [24,25]. As a consequence, many efforts have been attempted to incorporate the zirconia into support such as ZSM-5, SiO2, SBA-15, carbon nanofiber and MCM-41 to generate more accessibility of active species on the high surface area carriers for various processes [26–30]. In this work, the different methods to synthesize zirconia doped MCM-41 materials as a modified support to disperse active metal zinc as an effective catalyst for the acetylene hydration. The present study is to examine the influence of synthesized methods on the activity of zinc catalysts in the acetylene hydration, in other words, whether the synthesized methods for introducing zirconia species would affect the catalytic performance of zinc catalysts. And then, on basic of characterization and catalytic activity, the reasons of promote activity are proposed and discussed in detail. Importantly, the study of this work would provide scientific basis for the design of metal catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation In this work, the parent MCM-41 was synthesised by using the traditional hydrothermal treatment [31,32]. Typically, 1.82 g cetyltrimethylammonium bromide was mixed with a solution containing 0.2 M 45 mL of sodium hydroxide at 40 °C for 2 h. Then, 8.21 mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate was slowly added to the mixture under vigorous stirring for 2 h. else, the obtained solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon autoclave and placed in drying oven at 110 °C for 72 h. The white solid was filtered and washed thoroughly with deionized water until pH of 7 was reached. The powder was then dried at 60 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 6 h with airflow to obtain the MCM-41material. In addition, the Zr-MCM-41 materials were synthesized by four different methods, and zirconium oxychloride (ZrOCl2.8 H2O) as zirconia source. The specific synthesis process is as follows. (i) An impregnation method: 1.5 g of synthesised MCM-41was impregnated by the zirconia precursor solution, which was dissolves by deionized water with a certain amount of ZrOCl2.8 H2O. The mixing solution was magnetic stirred at 80 °C in the thermostatic oil bath. After 12 h, the obtained mixture was dried at 100 °C overnight. Finally, the solid powder was calcined at 550 °C for 3 h with airflow. (ii) The precipitation method: after the mixing solution was magnetic stirred for 4 h at room temperature, the solution pH was adjusted to 9–10 by the ammonium hydroxide solution. The whole stirring process lasted for 4 h again. After the solid was filtered and washed thoroughly with deionized water until pH of 7, the same rest procedure was followed the above process. (iii) The ultrasound method: the mixing solution was ultrasonic irradiated for 2 h with argon at ambient temperature. Then, the dry and calcination procedures were followed the above process. (iv) The trituration method: Certain amounts of ZrOCl2.8 H2O and MCM-41 were mixed in a ball mill at a rotation rate of 800 rpm for 1 h. After the dry and calcination procedures obtained the solid powder. Notably, the corresponding modified materials with the same zirconia content are named as ZM-I, ZM-P, ZM-U, ZM-T. The corresponding Zn catalysts of each modified support were synthesized by the wet impregnation technique with deionized water as a solvent. Briefly, a stoichiometric amount of ZnCl2 solution was added to the modified materials dropwise under magnetic stirring. The resulting suspension was stirred for 10 h in the environmental condition and then evaporated to dryness before the powder was further dried for 18 h at 100 °C to form the corresponding Zn catalysts, named as Zn/ZM-I, Zn/ZM-P, Zn/ZM-U, and Zn/ZM-T. Moreover, the same procedure was followed to prepare the corresponding Zn/MCM catalyst for comparison. The content of ZnCl2 was 10 wt% in all catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The synthesised zirconia-modified MCM-41 materials and their corresponding Zn catalysts were performed by a series of characterization techniques. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR): IS10 FT-IR spectrometer with wavelength range of 500–4000 cm−1. X-ray diffractometry (XRD): Bruker D8 advanced X-ray diffractometer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM): a JEM 2010 electron microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS): an Axis Ultra spectrometer with a monochromatized Al-Kα X-ray source. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET): a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD): an AutoChem 2720 instrument. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis: over the temperature range of 50–1000 °C with the heating rate of 20 °C/min and a nitrogen flow rate of 10 mL/min. UV–VIS spectra: a Hitachi UH4150 solid state UV–VIS spectrophotometer. ICP-AES: a Thermo Scientific iCAP 6000 instrument coupled to an inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES). 2.3 Performance evaluation In brief, the catalytic performance was tested in the fixed-bed glass microreactor for the hydration of acetylene. Firstly, in order to eliminate the air atmosphere of the reactor, the nitrogen was continued to purge for 30 min. Then, when the temperature of reactor reached to 240 °C, the reactant water was injected the reactor for 0.5 h by using a peristaltic pump. Else, the other reactant acetylene was poured into the system to react with water. Finally, the reaction products were detected by the gas chromatograph (GC-2014 C). In this work, the catalytic performance was tested using 2 mL catalyst in the fixed-bed glass microreactor (i. d. of 10 mm) for the hydration of acetylene, and the ZnCl2 loading is 10 wt% in the catalyst. In addition, acetylene conversion and selectivity to acetaldehyde are the performance indicators for the Zn catalyst, and the calculation equation is as follows: C 2 H 2 Conversion = C 2 H 2 feed − C 2 H 2 out C 2 H 2 feed × 100 % C 2 H 4 O Selectivity = C 2 H 4 O out C 2 H 2 feed − C 2 H 2 out × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterizations 3.1.1 FTIR and TG analysis The FTIR spectra of Zr-doped MCM-41 materials are presented in Fig. 1. All the Zr-doped MCM-41 materials showed the characteristic peaks at 805 cm−1, 960 cm−1, 1080 cm−1, 1238 cm−1, 1385 cm−1 and 1635 cm−1, which could be categorized as symmetric Si–O–Si stretch of the silica matrix, Si–O–H stretching vibrations, the asymmetry vibration of Si–O–Si and the bending vibrations of H–O–H, respectively [33]. Furthermore, the TGA results are revealed in Fig. 2 were carried out to examine the thermal stability of Zr-doped MCM-41 materials. It is clearly observed that all the modified materials exhibited various degrees of weight loss in the whole stages, and three temperature regions could be divided: (I) 50–150 °C, (II) 150–400 °C and (III) above 400 °C. In general, the weight loss of first region was attributed to the physically adsorbed water or/and other gases molecules on the modified materials external surface. Especially, the ZM-T material showed a higher rate weight loss than that of other Zr-doped MCM-41 materials. The next weight loss region maybe due to the condensation of hydroxyl groups linked to zirconium [34]. Else, the framework of modified materials might be progressively destroyed above 400 °C. As a whole, the ZM-I material displayed the excellent thermal stability than others. 3.1.2 BET and XRD analysis Fig. 3 shows the representative N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of modified materials and the corresponding Zn catalysts (shown in Fig. S1). According to the isotherms, all the modified materials and corresponding catalysts exhibited IV type isotherms and the similar hysteresis loops at 0.4﹤P/P0﹤0.9 indicated the mesoporous structure was still remained in the modified materials [35] (also see small-angle XRD and TEM data in later). Besides, the structure parameters in Table 1 showed that the synthesized ZM-I, ZM-P, ZM-U and ZM-T samples have the high surface area (963.6, 858.1, 828.8 and 737.7 m2 g−1, respectively) and the pore volume (1.0, 0.6, 0.7 and 0.7 cm3 g−1, respectively). In contrast to MCM-41 sample, the decrease of surface area and pore volume confirmed the zirconia incorporated into the MCM-41 structure. Moreover, doping materials with zinc species leaded to the further decrease in specific surface area and pore volume. It is can be explained that the zinc species cover on the surface of modified supports as well as the blockage of a portion of supports pore channels, which suggests that the degree of structural order reduced [36]. Meanwhile, Fig. 4A of small-angle XRD patterns clearly displayed the main peak at 2ϴ ≈ 2.4° classified as the (1 0 0) reflection, furthermore, other two (110) and (200) reflections were observed only for ZM-I material. These small-angle XRD reflections positions of the Zr-doped MCM-41 materials are characteristic of a hexagonal lattice mesostructures [37], and the order intensities of diffraction peaks is ZM-I﹥ZM-P﹥ZM-U﹥ZM-T. Notably, although the Zr-doped MCM-41 materials retained the mesoporous structure, the structural order of parent MCM-41 pore was destroyed. Furthermore, the diffraction peaks intensities obviously decreased after the zinc species impregnated on the surface of modified supports but also retained the mesoporous structure with poor structural order. From the wide-angle XRD patterns of Zr-doped MCM-41 materials in Fig. 4B, the obvious broad peak at 2ϴ ≈ 23° assigned to an amorphous MCM-41 support structure for Zr-doped MCM-41 materials. In addition, there is no diffraction peaks were assignable to the zirconia species of Zr-doped MCM-41 materials except for ZM-T material, indicating that no insufficiently exposed zirconia species due to these species were embedded in the pore walls of the framework, hence minimizing diffractions; the amorphous nature of zirconia species or/and the smaller particles size that below the detection limit of the XRD; preferential orientation of the metal particles in the MCM-41 matrix resulting in little or no diffractions. While, these sharp characteristic peaks of ZM-T material could be categorized as ZrO2 (PDF#37–1484) indicated the zirconia species covered on the external surface of MCM-41 material rather than doped into the framework structure. Likewise, the absence of zinc diffraction peaks (shown in Fig. S2) might suggest the particle size of the zinc species is below the detection limit of XRD or a large amount of amorphous active zinc species on the modified support surface. Else, the BET and XRD data also suggest the more optimal mesoporous structure of the ZM-I material by using the impregnation method. 3.1.3 TEM study The TEM experiment was used to deeply explore the morphology of all the samples. As shown in Fig. 5A, the regular long-range ordering of the mesoporous structure was retained for all the modified materials, indicating that the incorporation of zirconia species did not change the mesoporous structure by using the different preparation methods. However, some black particles species on the surface could be observed for the ZM-T material belonged to zirconia species that covered on the external surface rather than embedded into the framework of MCM-41. The results of TEM chimed in with the BET and XRD analysis. In addition, the absence of zirconia particles in other Zr-doped MCM-41 suggests the formation of Zr4+ ions that were incorporated into the mesoporous framework rather than the deposition of ZrO2 nanoparticles [38]. General views over the TEM images in Fig. 5B of the corresponding zinc catalysts expose that the morphology of mesoporous framework is virtually undamaged after the impregnation of zinc species, and the particles are uniformly dispersed on the support surface. In parallel to the results, the Zr-doped MCM-41 supported zinc catalysts displayed the better dispersion and smaller particles size than that of Zn/MCM catalyst (not shown), suggesting that the zirconia incorporated into the MCM-41 framework could improve the dispersion and control the particles size due to the strong metal-support interaction probably. But for the Zn/ZM-T sample, large aggregation of particles covered on the outer surface of modified support with the poorer dispersion, which is associated with the existential state of zirconia species in the Zn/ZM-T sample. The role of zirconia species covered on the MCM-41 surface is similar to the water off a duck's back instead of the benignant promotion that improves the dispersion and controls the particles size. 3.1.4 Solid-state UV–vis analysis To make sure a clear comprehending about the coordination of zirconia species in the framework and/or in the extra framework position, the solid-state UV–vis absorption technique was examined. The UV–vis absorption spectra of the Zr-doped MCM-41 materials and the corresponding Zn catalysts are diagrammed in Fig. 6. In the UV–vis spectra, two absorption peaks located at 220 nm and 290 nm could be clearly observed. According to the literature, the absorption band of pure ZrO2 is around 230 nm [39]. Hence, it is likely that the low wavelength bond could be classified as the low-energy charge transfer transition between oxygen and central Zr4+ ions with tetrahedral coordination, which substantiated the formation of Zr4+ ions that were incorporated into the mesoporous framework [40]. While on the ZM-T sample, the absorption bond at 230 nm similar to that of pure ZrO2 reveals that zirconia additive exist in the form of ZrO2 species covered on the outer surface rather than embedded into the framework of MCM-41 through the Zr4+ ions, which is in accordance with those above characterization analysis. On the other hand, the other bond at high wavelength might be the formation of amorphous ZrO2 with the small particle size on the modified materials outer surface [41], and these particles could not be detected by the XRD. In addition, the modified Zn catalysts showed the similar UV–vis absorption spectra (shown in Fig. S3) like that of the Zr-doped MCM-41 materials, but the decrease of intensities absorption band located at 220 nm and 290 nm as a result of the zinc species impregnation. The addition of Zn species did not destroy or influence the existence form of Zr species in the MCM-41 framework. 3.2 Catalysis performance The catalytic performance is one of the important criteria to evaluate a catalyst. In view of this, the catalytic performances of modified Zn catalysts were investigated in a fixed-bed microreactor for the hydration of acetylene (H2O(g)/C2H2 = 4, gas hourly space velocity = 90 h−1 and reaction temperature = 240 °C), and the tested results were plotted in Fig. 7. Clearly, the Zn/MCM catalyst showed a high initial activity with 83% C2H2 conversion but reduced to about 40% after 15 h, and the selectivity to acetaldehyde is above 80% within the first 4 h of the reaction while eventually decreased to 60% during the reaction 15 h. The poor catalytic stability has been identified with the previous reports. In addition, the Zn/ZrO2 catalyst contributed to the poorest catalytic activity and selectivity. On the contrary, the synthesized Zn/Zr-MCM catalysts displayed the better catalytic performance under the same reaction condition. To be more specific, the Zn/ZM-I catalyst showed the highest activity of 95% C2H2 conversion during the reaction of 4 h, while the further increasing reaction time resulted in a tardily reduced of activity with about 83% after 15 h. The C2H2 conversion of the Zn/ZM-P catalyst up to 98% at the first 6 h then slight decreased with the time on stream until to 92% after 15 h. Moreover, the C2H2 conversion of Zn/ZM-U catalyst is close to that of Zn/ZM-I catalyst and appeared the similar deactivation trend during the reaction process. However, the Zn/ZM-T catalyst presented the maximum deactivation rate than that of other modified Zn catalysts. Meanwhile, the selectivity to acetaldehyde improved greatly contrasted with the Zn/MCM catalyst. In detail, the selectivity is about 80% for the modified Zn catalysts except for Zn/ZM-T catalyst, and the higher selectivity could be belonged to the Zn/ZM-P catalyst with around 85% selectivity to acetaldehyde. These above results suggest the incorporation of zirconia dramatically enhanced the catalytic performance, and the Zn/ZM-P catalyst exhibits the higher activity. In other words, the different preparation methods for adding zirconia species would exert influence on the catalytic performance of modified Zn catalysts in the acetylene hydration. In brief, two different types of zirconia species were introduced into the MCM-41 material: Zr4+ ions embedded into the framework and ZrO2 species covered on the surface. As it turns out, the former is in favor of catalytic performance of Zn catalysts rather than that of the latter. In addition, although the same existential form of zirconia species in the Zn/ZM-I, Zn/ZM-P and Zn/ZM-U catalysts, the diverse catalytic performance of these above catalysts were still observed in the Fig. 7. It is reasonable that the preparation methods would also be effect the content of Zr species, as well as the metal-support interactions, which is a key bridge for the metal dispersion. As discussed above, the better dispersion and smaller particles size owing to the strong metal-support interactions of the Zn/ZM-I, Zn/ZM-P and Zn/ZM-U catalysts could be considered as the reasons for the high catalytic performance in the acetylene hydration. 3.3 NH3-TPD analysis To assess the concentration and acid sites strength of the Zr-doped MCM-41 materials and zinc catalysts, the NH3-TPD experiments have been invited and the data is listed in Fig. 8 and Table 1. As can be seen in Fig. 8A, all the Zr-doped MCM-41 materials have a desorption peak of unequal area around 300 °C − 500 °C, which was classified as medium and strong acid sites [42]. Furthermore, on the basic of desorption area of NH3 data for the Zr-doped MCM-41 materials, the ZM-P sample is followed by ZM-U and ZM-I samples (neck and neck of these two samples) with the maximum desorption area of NH3 data, and the ZM-T sample was one of the worst. The characterization results suggest that the introduction of zirconia species increased the acidity of MCM-41 material and had a dramatically influence on the distribution of the acid strength and total acid quantity. In addition, as shown the NH3-TPD profiles of corresponding modified Zn catalysts in the Fig. 8B, the Zn/MCM catalyst exhibited three desorption peaks around 200 °C, 375 °C and 500 °C, corresponding to weak, medium and strong acid sites, respectively. The modified Zn catalysts had a broad desorption peak around 150 °C − 400 °C involving weak, medium and strong acid sites. It is worth noting that total acid quantity of modified Zn catalyst is much more than that of Zn/MCM catalyst from the data in Table 1, especially for the Zn/ZM-P catalyst, and the acid quantity of Zn/ZM-I catalyst was equally matched to Zn/ZM-U catalyst. In general, the acidity of molecular sieve catalysts has a great influence on the catalytic performance. In our previous research, the improvement of catalytic performance as a result of enhancement of acid strength and total acid quantity for the modified MCM-41 and ZSM-5 supported Zn catalysts in the hydration of acetylene. These could be explained that the higher catalytic performance of modified Zn catalysts, as well as the excellent activity of Zn/ZM-P catalyst. Additionally, it is clearly observed that the improvement of catalytic performance with the increase of acid quantity, and the latter is well correlated with the incremental Zr content from the Fig. 9. Furthermore, the more weak and medium acid sites generated suggests that the interaction between Zn species and Zr modified MCM-41 materials. Notably, the metal-support interactions would enrich more Zn species and enhance the dispersion of Zn species. The reduced of strong acid sites might be responsible for the increment of selectivity to acetaldehyde for the modified Zn catalysts [43]. 3.4 H2-TPR analysis The reducibility and the metal-support interaction of modified Zn catalysts have been measured by using H2-TPR technology. In general, it is hard to be reduced of the pure Si-MCM-41and Zr modified MCM-41. Therefore, the detected reduction peak is most likely from the surface zinc species. As the detected in our previous works, the reduction peak of zinc species is around 400 °C [10,11]. Fig. 10 showed the reduction peak of modified Zn catalysts of the H2-TPR profiles. Clearly, the grotesque reduction peaks of zinc species were related to the addition forms for the zirconia species. First, a broad reduced shoulder peak at 400–650 °C was found for the Zn/ZM-I catalyst, two convex peaks around 440 °C could be attributed to the reduction of zinc species dispersed on the support external surface, and the other high reduction temperature at 500 °C might be the reduction of the zinc species with strong interaction between the ZM-I support, and the explanations could be also suitable for the Zn/ZM-U catalyst. Then, the main reduction peak located at 530 °C suggests the stronger interaction between zinc species and the ZM-P support for the Zn/ZM-P catalyst. However, the Zn/ZM-T catalyst showed a broader peak around 300–620 °C. It might be speculated that there are three existence forms of zinc species: (i) parts of zinc species dispersed on the external surface of MCM-41; (ii) a portion of zinc species dispersed on the ZrO2 surface; (iii) a spot of zinc species having the interaction between the ZM-T support. These results point out that the introduction of zirconia enhanced the metal-support interaction and the increase order as follows: Zn/ZM-T＜Zn/ZM-U＜Zn/ZM-I＜Zn/ZM-P. It is could be explained that the inherent hydroxyl groups of MCM-41 surface might be replaced by the hydroxyl groups of additive zirconia, which would be more active for the interaction with the deposited Zn species. Well-known, the stronger interaction represents the better dispersion for the metal catalysts, and the TEM in Fig. 5 confirmed the better dispersion of the Zn/ZM-P catalyst. In addition, the activity results in Fig. 7 indicated the Zn/ZM-P catalyst displayed the best catalytic performance. These all could be ascribed to the stronger interaction between zinc species and ZM-P support. In a summary, the introduction of zirconia enhanced the metal-support interaction and improved the zinc species dispersion on the support, which could be responsible for the high catalytic performance of the Zn catalysts in the acetylene hydration. 3.5 TEM analysis of the spent catalysts The situation of surface structure and particles agglomeration for the spent modified Zn catalysts were also carried out by using TEM technique, and the images were illustrated in Fig. 11. In a glance, the Zn/ZM-P catalyst showed the better particle dispersion and smaller particle than that of other modified Zn catalysts after the reaction. In contrast to the fresh catalysts, less serious particles agglomerations of the Zn/ZM-I and Zn/ZM-U catalysts were observed after the reaction, notably, the complex surface composition such as Zn, Zr, Si and C of the spent catalysts, suggesting that visible particles with various size on the external support surface could be one or two or all of them that Zn particles, ZrO2, carbon deposition. That is impossible to distinguish them strictly due to the low contrast among these particles in the TEM images. However, the severely agglomeration of Zn/ZM-T catalyst may be responsible for the poor stability during the reaction. In addition, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR have revealed the interaction between zinc and zirconia species in the modified Zn catalysts; in fact, the interaction not only enhances a good dispersion but also controls the Zn particles size. Notably, the addition of zirconia prevents particles agglomeration and enriches more Zn species. Hence, these features could be the reason of high activity for the modified Zn catalysts in the hydration of acetylene. 3.6 XPS analysis In the next moment, the XPS technology was carried out to ascertain the surface states and compositions of elements, including Zn 2p, O 1s and Zr 3d of the fresh and spent catalysts, and the results are plotted in Fig. 12, Fig. S4, Table 2 and Table S1. Obviously, there are two types of Zn peaks in the fresh zirconia-modified Zn catalysts by fitting the Zn 2p3/2 XPS spectra. In detail, the peaks at the binding energies of 1023.0 and 1023.7 eV, 1022.8 and 1023.5 eV, 1023.0 and 1023.6 eV, and 1022.8 and 1023.5 eV for the corresponding fresh Zn/ZM-I, Zn/ZM-P, Zn/ZM-U and Zn/ZM-T catalysts, respectively. In our previous works, the Zn species were found at 1024.0 eV and 1023.2 eV belonged to the (ZnOH)+ and (ZnH)+ species for the fresh Zn/MCM catalyst [10,11]. The shift of Zn 2p3/2 XPS peaks to lower binding energies after the incorporation of zirconia suggests that the Zn species obtain more electrons from the modified support, which is related to the strong metal-support interaction. In addition, the low binding energy of Zn species could be classified to (ZnH)+ species because of the hydrodehydroxylation of (ZnOH)+ species, which in connection with the closer interaction with modified support framework; and the other at high binding energy of Zn species might be belonged to (ZnOH)+ species. Furthermore, the integral area of (ZnOH)+ species is much more than that of (ZnH)+ species for all the fresh samples, which indicates that most of Zn species were mainly existed in the form of isolated (ZnOH)+ cationic species. However, the slight shift to low energy could be noted for all the spent Zn catalysts with binding energies around 1022.8 and 1023.4 eV belonged to the (ZnOZn)2+ and (ZnH)+ species [44,45]. It is important to notice that the formation of (ZnOZn)2+ species was contributed to the dehydration of (ZnOH)+ species due to the stronger interaction with the modified support during the reaction process. The O 1s XPS spectra of the modified Zn catalysts have been deconvoluted into three peaks with the binding energies around 533.4 eV, 532.7 eV, and 532.1 eV, which could be attributed to the physisorbed-O, regular lattice-O, and the hydroxyl (-OH) species, respectively [46]. In general, the different O species with different binding energies might be as a result of the asymmetric of O 1s XPS peaks. It is clearly that the estimated relative content of O species based on the integral area increase order as follows: hydroxyl-O＜regular lattice-O＜physisorbed-O, but except for the Zn/ZM-P sample with the most regular lattice-O and minimum of physisorbed-O. In compared with O 1 s XPS peaks of fresh Zn/MCM catalyst, the intensities of O 1 s XPS peak decreased and negative shifted of binding energies for the zirconia-modified Zn catalysts. Moreover, it should be noted that no O 1 s peaks corresponding to SiO2 and ZrO2 individually appear in the O 1s XPS spectra of modified materials. All above features suggest that the chemical interaction between zirconia and parent support with each other in the modified materials, which could enrich more metal species and control the metal particles size for the metal-support catalysts in the heterogeneous catalysis. For the spent samples, the negative shift of binding energy and increase of regular lattice O content would speculate the strong interaction appeared at zirconia and Zn species or/and support framework during the reaction. In a general way, the binding energy of the Zr 3d5/2 around 182.4 eV and 180.0 eV can be noted in the pure ZrO2 and zirconium metal samples [47,48]. However, for the zirconia-modified materials, the Zr 3d5/2 XPS peaks were coincidentally divided into two different Zr species peaks with the binding energies around 183.5 eV and 182.8 eV except to the Zn/ZM-T catalyst (around 182.4 eV and 182.0 eV). The binding energy at 182.4 eV of Zn/ZM-T catalyst is attributed to pure ZrO2 that indicates there are portions of ZrO2 covered the external surfaces, consisting with the XRD and solid-state UV–vis results. While for other three zirconia-modified materials, the binding energies of Zr 3d5/2 XPS peaks is higher than that of pure ZrO2 denotes the formation of Zr4+ ions incorporating into the mesoporous framework rather than the ZrO2 species. On the other hand, the positive shift also suggests the tiger interactions at the modified support surface and Zr sites as an electron-donating power. As the above stated, Zn 2p3/2 XPS peaks obtain more electrons from the modified support after the incorporation of zirconia, in other word, the strong metal-support interaction is as a result of the charge transfer from zirconium to zinc. In addition, the obvious variations of the intensity and binding energy for Zr 3d5/2 XPS peaks for the all spent catalysts are the further evidences of the strong metal-support interaction during the acetylene hydration reaction. The surface relative elemental compositions were also calculated by the XPS technology. Depending on the different preparation methods, the introduction way of zirconia species makes a difference on the relative elemental compositions, especially for the content of Zr species. According to the result of ICP-AES in Table S2 (in the Supporting information) and Table 2, the increase order of Zr content as follows: Zn/ZM-T＜Zn/ZM-I≈Zn/ZM-U＜Zn/ZM-P, in other words, more content of Zr species could be obtained by using the precipitation method, and this could be the evidence of more acid sites detecting by NH3-TPD for the Zn/ZM-P catalyst, as well as the most regular lattice-O in the Zn/ZM-P sample. Furthermore, the variations of Zn 2p3/2 and Zr 3d5/2 XPS peaks confirm the presence of charge transfer from zirconium to zinc, hence, more electron densities of Zn species would be responsible for the higher catalytic performance for the Zn/ZM-P catalyst in the acetylene hydration. On the contrary, the Zn/ZM-T catalyst showed the lower activity with the least content of Zr species, which could be explained that most of zirconia species covered on the MCM-41 surface by physical mixing with weak metal-support interaction and poor metal dispersion. In addition, there is no obvious distinction of the Zr species content in the Zn/ZM-I and Zn/ZM-U catalysts, as well as the same to their catalytic performance in the hydration of acetylene due to the good metal dispersion and strong metal-support interaction as discussed in the TEM and H2-TPR studies. As well, the content of Zr species decreased slightly for the spent catalysts owing to (i) parts of Zr species were covered by the coking carbon or/and polymers on the external surface; (ii) a port of Zr species with weak interaction might run off during the reaction. After all, the XPS is just a surface technique to measure the external surface species with the sampling depth about 3–10 nm. In addition, the active metal content also is an important fact for the high catalytic performance; generally, more active metal content would contribute more active sites during the proper metal loading. The metal elements content of the all catalysts would be detected by the ICP-AES, and the results were listed in the Table S2 in the Supporting information. The results clearly indicated that the modified Zn catalysts have the more active Zn atomic content (3.78%, 3.96%, 3.67% and 3.44%) than that of Zn/MCM catalyst (3.24%), which indicates the addition of zirconia could enrich more active Zn species. Moreover, the loss ratio of active Zn species decreased order as follows during the reaction: S-Zn/ZM-P(3.3%)＜S-Zn/ZM-I(5.0%)＜S-Zn/ZM-U(5.7%)＜S-Zn/ZM-T(12.5%)＜S-Zn/MCM (25.3%). Meanwhile, from the results of Table 2, the XPS results are consistent with ICP-AES results. These results indicated the inhibition of active Zn species loss during the reaction by the addition of zirconia owing to the strong metal-support interactions. These are the key factors of the high activity for the Zn catalysts in the acetylene hydration. Anything else, compared with the fresh catalysts, it is no marked distinction of the oxygen content but with slight reduced for the spent catalysts. In contrast to the variation tendency of oxygen content, carbon content minor increased after the reaction because of the coke deposition, but the amount of coke carbon is less than that of spent Zn/MCM catalyst during the reaction. In our previous studies, the active Zn loss and coke carbon would contribute to the rapid deactivation of the Zn/MCM catalyst during the acetylene hydration reaction; however, the incorporation of zirconia into support framework to surmount the above drawbacks to obtain the high activity and stability catalysts, which is in accordance with our original experimental design. As seen in the Table 2, 4 Conclusions In this study, four different preparation methods for introducing zirconia species into framework of parent MCM-41 material as modified support to disperse active Zn species used as highly effective catalysts to catalyze the hydration of acetylene. All the modified Zn catalysts showed the promotional catalytic performance than that of the Zn/MCM catalyst. Among them, the Zn/ZM-P catalyst displayed the more optimistic catalytic performance with above 92% C2H2 conversion and 85% selectivity to acetaldehyde in the acetylene hydration, and followed by the Zn/ZM-I and Zn/ZM-U catalysts. On the basis of characterization and analysis, the following conclusions are mainly drawn. The BET and XRD results confirm that the mesoporous structure still remained but with poor pore order after the incorporation of zirconia species for all synthesized materials with satisfied specific surface area. The results of TGA suggest that synthesized Zr-MCM materials, especially for ZM-I, displayed the excellent thermal stability. The better metal dispersion and smaller active Zn species on the external surface of modified ZM-P support could be obverted from the TEM images. On the basis of solid-state UV–vis results, the central Zr ions with tetrahedral coordination embedded into the mesoporous framework for the ZM-I, ZM-P and ZM-U samples, but the ZrO2 species covered on the outer surface of ZM-T sample. The H2-TPR experiments verify the zirconia species addition could enhance the interactions between active Zn species and modified support, which would further enrich more active species and control the particles size with high dispersion. According to the NH3-TPD, the substantial enhancement of acid sites (more weak and medium acid sites but the reduced of strong acid sites) and total acid quantity for the modified materials were contributed to the zirconia species addition, especially for the Zn/ZM-P catalyst. The XPS results revel that the presence of electron transfers that Zn species obtain more electrons from the Zr-modified support, as well as prevent active Zn species loss and coke carbon during the reaction by the addition of zirconia. coredata.dc:description: The ordered mesoporous Zr-modified MCM-41 materials were synthesized by using four different preparation methods including impregnation method, precipitation method, ultrasound method and trituration method, respectively; active zinc species were immobilized on the modified materials with different methods for introducing zirconia species as effective catalysts for the acetylene hydration. All the synthesized materials were characterized by various techniques including BET, FTIR, XRD, TGA, TEM, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, and solid-stated UV–vis. The correlation between structural properties of zirconia modified support and catalytic performance of the Zn catalysts was evaluated in detailed in the acetylene hydration. It is demonstrate that the Zr-modified materials showed the excellent thermostability, and zirconia species addition could enhance the interactions between active metal and support, as well as control the metal particles size with better dispersion. In addition, the substantial enhancement of acid sites and total acid quantity for the modified materials were contributed to the zirconia species addition. Besides, activity evaluation confirms that the Zn/ZM-P catalyst showed more optimistic catalytic performance above 92% C2H2 conversion and 85% selectivity to acetaldehyde in the acetylene hydration due to the stronger metal-support interactions and more acid sites. The study would provide scientific basis for the design of metal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic acetylene hydration over the Zn/Zr-MCM catalyst: Effect of preparation methods for doping zirconia on catalytic performance
